Sentence: In the third act, set in Lord Goring's home, Goring receives a pink letter from Lady Chiltern asking for his (Goring) help, a letter that might be read as a compromising love note
Cheveley steals Lady Chiltern's note from his (Goring) desk
Lady Chiltern then appears, and Lord Goring informs her (Chiltern) that Sir Robert's letter has been destroyed but that Mrs
The ever-upright Lady Chiltern then attempts to drive Sir Robert to renounce his (Robert) career in politics, but Lord Goring dissuades her (Chiltern) from doing so
